title: Ticket #3276: Improve blahp file handling
description:
We need to reduce the number of orphaned files the blahp can leave behind.

Work Plan

We know from user reports that the blahp can leave behind orphaned files and directories that are never cleaned up. We looked over the user reports and audited the blahp's file usage to identify cases affecting the Condor-CE that we can fix. We identified two cases that required addressing. They can be handled with changes primarily to the condor_gridmanager, with minimal changes to the blahp.

First case: For most batch systems, the blahp wraps the job with a script that manages the job's execution environment. The script creates a directory under the user's home directory in which to run the job. Once the job completes, it moves output files out of the directory and deletes it. Under the right circumstances, this directory may not be removed. When the user's home directory is shared (common for PBS, LSF and SGE clusters), the gridmanager can check for the existence of this directory and remove it after job completion. This requires that the gridmanager know the name of the directory. Currently, the directory's name is choosen at random by the blahp's submit script. We can add an optional attribute to the job description given to the blahp that dictates the name of the directory.

Second case: When a job has an X.509 proxy, the blahp creates a limited proxy from the given one, using the same filename with ".lmt" appended. It then creates a symlink under $(HOME)/.blah_jobproxy_dir/ to the limited proxy. The name of the symlink is based on the blahp's job id. For some batch systems, the status script removes the symlink when returning a job status of 3 (REMOVED) or 4 (COMPLETED). In many situations, the symlink can get left behind. We can remove the symlink in the gridmanager after the job completes. If the limited proxy resides in the Condor spool directory, the gridmanager can also remove the limited proxy. We can't remove the limited proxy if it's outside the spool directory, as it could be shared by multiple jobs, some of which may still be running.
